description: World War I British and ANZAC army slang, probably a corruption of French “il n′y a plus” (“there is no more”).

entries.meaning: (military slang, now historical) Finished, dead, no more, gone; non-existent. [from 20th c.]
examples: What shall I do? / My poor old dug-out is napoo.
‘Yes. He was out on a listening post and lit a cigarette. Sniper got him.’

verbs.description: napoo (third-person singular simple present napoos, present participle napooing, simple past and past participle napooed)

entries.meaning: (UK, army, slang) To finish; to put an end to; to kill.
